posts.name: Allen Cooke
posts.cooked:
My team is using suction to hold game pieces. We want to be able to instantly vent the suction to the atmosphere to place game pieces faster, but we are struggling to plumb the solenoid.

The solenoids that we have are air piloted, so will port P need to be connected to the pneumatic system, or would it be possible to attach the vacuum pump to ports 4 or 2?

What we want:

One state that closes the vent and allows us to use the vacuum (suction grabs)

Another state that vents the vacuum to the atmosphere (suction releases)

Is this possible and legal? If so, how would it be done?

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
How are you generatimg vacuum?

You could plumb the solenoid to P and vaccuum to a vent port.  Use a throttle valve upsteam.  Shifting the valve takes you from vac to pressure.

Need to.test, of course!

posts.name: Allen Cooke
posts.cooked: We are using a vacuum pump that we bought on Amazon and replaced the motor. Do you have an example of a throttle valve?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
I dont have rules handy to speak to legality if doing so, so I’ll let others jump in for that.  The rest of this comment should be viewed as a thought experiment until proven legal.

I also dont have specs for that specific valve, so you’ll have to test to confirm.

As you mentioned, solenoid valves are often piloted, meaning there’s a minimum amount of (positive) pressure needed in the inlet port (P) for it to function.  That pressure is typically 15-20psi I believe.  At any given point, either port 2 or 4 will be connected to P, and the other will be connected to its adsoviated exhaust port (1 or 5).  So for this to work, the vacuum system will need to be connected to either 1 or 2, or 4 or 5.  In order to not bleed your positive pressure to atmosphere, ports 2 and 4 will need to be a closed system (or plugged), which a vacuum system will very likely not be.  That leaves 1 or 5, which are functionally equivalent (essentially the same as NO vs NC on a limit switch).  In order for that to work, it’s paired port (2 or 4) will need to be open to atmosphere (or at least non-negative pressure).

In short, the only way I see this working is if you use a different valve that does not require pilot pressure, or if you accept bleeding your positive pressure to atmosphere through your vacuum system.

Edit: unless there’s some other kind of pneumatic valve/device I’m not currently aware of, but that would be another purchase.

posts.name: Scott McRoberts
posts.cooked: We used vacuum on our bot for our first comp. It worked just fine without a solenoid. Just a line straight from the pump to 2 suction cups. When the pump shuts off it loses suction pretty fast. For our 2nd comp we have moved towards rollers instead of suction grippers.

posts.name: Mr V
posts.cooked:
While it would be possible to make it work with the standard valve, as an LRI I’d have to escalate to HQ on that set up since I haven’t seen any guidance on crossing pressure and vacuum.

Something that should work fine w/o any legality concerns would be to run the vacuum’s motor in reverse.

Another option would be to use a simple electric valve that is Tee’d into the hose running to the gripper. One like this. https://www.amazon.com/Vixen-Air-VXF2038-NPT-Solenoid/dp/B073MNVNSM You could likely control it with the switched circuit on the PDH if you have that, or you’ll need a relay. They are available in several orifice sizes.

Most of the amazon vacuum pumps have check valves in them and running the pump in reverse stalls the motor (we found this out on accident haha).

We used a valve similar to this teed into the line like you said.

We are also using a vacuum sensor which lets us know when we have a game piece and allows us to run the vacuum motor intermittently by monitering the pressure.
